user.biography: #OceanX is a mission to explore the ocean and bring it back to the world. Operating from Earth’s greatest research vessel, #OceanXplorer.

node.text:
Taking the #POV trend to a whole new level: these cameras are loaded with bait (dead fish) and placed underwater to get a firsthand view what’s going on under the surface. Baited Remote Underwater Videos (BRUVs) are deployed strategically just long enough to show who lives nearby, how many, and how big they are, and often capture behaviors that would go unseen otherwise. Here’s how marine biologists used BRUVs to explore the reef ecosystems of the northern Red Sea, including viewing the big predators who live there, and capturing some incredible footage along the way.
#oceanx #marinebiology #reef #underwater #discovery

node.title: Underwater Camera Spies On Big Reef Predators

node.text:
Recent research has unveiled #whaleshark “hotspots” in the #RedSea that they return to annually, including a large number of young whale sharks. But those are much farther south. Now, Dr. Jesse Cochran, a leading whale shark researcher, is on mission with us in the northern Red Sea. His mission is to find and tag a whale shark in a region where we know almost nothing about them. What will happen is a first for us, and for him. 

#oceanx #marinebiology #discovery #oceanlife #gulfofaqaba #egypt #middleeast

node.title: Watch an amazing moment aboard the #OceanXplorer

node.text:
The colossal squid is the world's largest invertebrate. It can grow to 14m (46 ft) and weigh over 500 kg (~1,000 lbs). Scientists don't know very much about them, because they are elusive and live at depths below 1,000 m (3,200 feet) in the waters around Antarctica. Only a few specimens have ever been observed by scientists, usually as bycatch in deep-sea fisheries. We asked marine scientist @wild.blue.science to design his dream mission using all the capabilities of our ship the #OceanXplorer. His answer? Find and observe a living colossal squid in the wild. 🎨: @johanpapin

#science #adventure #exploration

Now #surfing is officially an #Olympic sport, artificial wave pools like this one by @urbnsurf will help athletes get as many waves as they want, in almost any condition they want.

#summer #summerolympics #tokyo

node.text:
You, an intellectual: already knows the Greenland shark lives for centuries…. But HOW do they know that? 

This species has the nerve to be the hardest to age. With sharks, scientist can usually count the growth layers of cartilage that hardens over time, but the Greenland shark doesn't have any hard bits ("it's a very soft shark," according to scientist Julius Nielsen).

So scientists just decided to use a technique used on humans. 

Also, a correction (me: not an intellectual): In the video, I say “usually, you can tell how old a shark is by checking the rings in their earbones” but that doesn’t apply to sharks.

Source (actual intellectuals): 

Lynnerup N, Kjeldsen H, Heegaard S, Jacobsen C, Heinemeier J (2008) Radiocarbon Dating of the Human Eye Lens Crystallines Reveal Proteins without Carbon Turnover throughout Life. PLOS ONE 3(1): e1529. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0001529

Nielsen J, Hedeholm R, Heinemeier J, Bushnell P, Christiansen J, Olsen J, Bronk Ramsey C, Brill R, Simon M, Steffensen K, Steffensen J. Eye lens radiocarbon reveals centuries of longevity in the Greenland shark (Somniosus microcephalus). Science. 2016; 353(6300):702-704.  DOI: 10.1126/science.aaf1703

node.title: How Do We Know How Old This Shark Is?

node.text:
Coral reefs are often called the canary in the coal mine -- they’re extremely sensitive to slight changes in ocean conditions, and a leading indicator for how other ecosystems will respond to a changing climate. They’ve been around for 400 million years, but now they’re on track to disappear within a few decades. 

The corals in the Red Sea could hold the key to preserving other reefs, because they live in very warm, very salty water--conditions that mimic what the global ocean will look like in the coming decades. If we can figure out what mechanisms Red Sea corals use to thrive, scientists are hopeful we can take that knowledge and apply it to save coral reefs around the world.

From aboard the OceanXplorer during its maiden mission to the Red Sea, marine scientist Dr. Sam Purkis opens up about the frightening discoveries he makes studying the health of Red Sea coral reefs (including submarine dives up to 700 meters), and what they mean for the future of the ocean, and what he wants Gen-Z and future generations to know about what it will take to turn this around.

#science #ocean #submarine #coralreefs #RedSea

Calling From The Coral

node.text:
On its maiden mission to the Red Sea, #OceanXplorer made a surprising discovery: a brine pool, over 1700 meters below the surface, teeming with otherworldly life—extremophiles, to be precise, lifeforms that survive in conditions we wouldn't believe possible on our planet, and which provide clues to how life on Earth began. This is the first ever brine pool discovered in the Gulf of Aqaba, in the northern Red Sea. 

Director: Tommy Davis
Executive Producers: Mark Dalio, Joe Ruffolo, Jonathan Schienberg
Senior Producer: Erika Jarvis
Producers: Mika Chance, Carly Tarricone
Story Producer: Lindsay Blatt

Underwater Series DP: Sean Ruggeri
DP: Tommy Davis
Post Production Supervisor: Gabe Tanenhaus
Editors: Tommy Davis, Nick Capezzera
Assistant Editors: Patrick Hopkins, Carly Tarricone
Sound: Tommy Davis
Color Grade: Running Man Post

#oceanx #ocean #discovery #exploration

node.text:
In 1962, John F Kennedy made a speech that launched what became known as the space race and committed the nation to the ambitious goal of landing on the Moon by the end of the decade. 
 
Almost 60 years later we have achieved thrilling feats of universal exploration that would surpass even Kennedy's wildest dreams, and at the same time we're beginning to understand the incredibly fragile and exquisite uniqueness of our own little planet. The UN declared 2021 the beginning of the Decade of Ocean Science, to emphasize the importance of understanding and protecting our (largely unexplored) planetary life-support system. And yet—fewer people probably know about that than they do about our recent forays to Mars or the FBI's upcoming declassification of sealed documents about UFOs. 

That's OK, but this #WorldOceansWeek, we want to remind people that there's also a whole "universe" out there waiting to be explored—and it's right here in our own oceans. The oceans are the source of life on Earth, and the answer to some of our greatest challenges. It's not rocket science. So follow us as we #ExploreWhatMatters.

node.title: Why ocean exploration matters more than space

node.text:
Taking the #POV trend to a whole new level: these cameras are loaded with bait (dead fish) and placed underwater to get a firsthand view what’s going on under the surface. Baited Remote Underwater Videos (BRUVs) are deployed strategically just long enough to show who lives nearby, how many, and how big they are, and often capture behaviors that would go unseen otherwise. Here’s how marine biologists used BRUVs to explore the reef ecosystems of the northern Red Sea, including viewing the big predators who live there, and capturing some incredible footage along the way.
#oceanx #marinebiology #reef #underwater #discovery

node.text:
This is a crown of thorns sea star. It's a reef inhabitant that eats #coral. If you look closely, there's a red dot on the end of its arm that serves as a very, very primitive eye. It can detect light, but its vision is not super hot—it works sort of like a long exposure on a camera, so if a fish moves by too quickly, it won't be able to see it too well. The cool part is that, with an eye spot on the end of every arm, it can detect visual stimuli from every direction, giving it a 360 view. Filmed in the #RedSea.

📷: @buckarooshooter

#RedSea #beauty #underwater #beautiful #nature #naturephotography #starfish #crownofthorns #coralreefs

node.text:
What you're seeing here is the track made by #OceanXplorer whilst doing some water column mapping in the #Atlantic. We moved back and forth whilst sending out pings from our "fishery sonar"* to look at what is in the water column at different time and size scales; those yellow and green blobs are actually swarms of fish/plankton/miscellaneous living things. Oh yeah, and that seafloor map (the bumps and mountains and stuff) was done by us too. ☺️ 📷: @tomer.here.there.everywhere

*It's called an EK80. It's cool. 

#science #seabed2030 #maps #geography #bathymetry #exploration #oceanexploration #oceanx

node.text:
This is a comb jelly and it is responsible for a raging BEEF between evolutionary biologists about whether it was the first animal on #Earth—the one that everything else descended from. Until fairly recently, that honor went to the sea sponge, which, in spite of looking like something from Salvador Dali painting is, in fact, an animal. It's said the Europeans prefer the (original) sponge-first hypothesis, whereas North Americans tend to like the newer idea that comb jellies came first. Contentious! The weird thing about the comb jelly is that it has nerves and a digestive system, which is a whole lot more than sea sponges can lay claim to; this also means if comb jellies came first, then sponges decided they didn't need all those extra features and were just fine pretending to be sperm-producing rocks, when USUALLY species get more complex over evolutionary time.

Sooooo… last year this study (1) came out swinging saying that Team Comb Jelly had made an error in their accounting (or, that "topology-dependent asymmetry in systematic errors affects phylogenetic placement of Ctenophora and Xenacoelomorpha," in plain English.) 
Basically, because comb jellies evolved really fast, it makes them look genetically like they've been around a lot longer than they have. But this paper thinks that sponges actually did come first. Not sure what the response was from Team Comb Jelly, perhaps they're seething, but things move slowly in evolutionary #science, appropriately.  

*Although it's not a jellyfish at all, it's in its own whole group called #ctenophores, pronounced "tee-no-fors".
 
(1) Kapli, P., & Telford, M. J. (2020). Topology-dependent asymmetry in systematic errors affects phylogenetic placement of Ctenophora and Xenacoelomorpha. Science Advances, 6(50), eabc5162. https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.abc5162
 #invertebrates #ocean #blueplanet2

node.text:
#OceanXplorer update: Repost from @oceanxplorer_zoleka
•
What a jam packed day filled with new experiences! From loosening my umbilical cord with the mothership, skippering the FRS, stepping on northern ground, and glacier hiking. 

The geometry of the glacier front, cryoconite holes, and solid (but wet) layers of ice reminded me of the laws of physics that govern matter. So strong, yet they cannot be seen. 

My heart is left fuzzy, and it’s this feeling that will carry me through the strides I am yet to take.

node.text:
#OceanNews: We don’t know how the #whale calf died—it was too chewed up by the time they got to it, but as research ecologist David Wiley told LiveScience: “Everything dies for something else to consume. Nothing goes to waste.” The surface predators get first dibs before it eventually sinks to the sea floor where it will decompose and feed deep ocean communities over several years. It’s reported there were eight (or more) massive sharks around—one of which was 20 feet?!—and they got acoustic tags on five which is a huge number for one afternoon! The tags will tell researchers (who can only do this with very specific permits) where the #sharks are going over coming weeks. 📹: @noaasanctuaries @noaa 

#capecod #massachusetts #sharklove #science #natureismetal 

“#

node.text:
Taking the #POV trend to a whole new level: these cameras are loaded with bait (dead fish) and placed underwater to get a firsthand view what’s going on under the surface. Baited Remote Underwater Videos (BRUVs) are deployed strategically just long enough to show who lives nearby, how many, and how big they are, and often capture behaviors that would go unseen otherwise. Here’s how marine biologists (@francesco.garzon) used BRUVs to explore the reef ecosystems of the northern Red Sea, including viewing the big predators who live there, and capturing some incredible footage along the way.

Watch the full video at bit.ly/BRUV-OCEANX or at the link in our bio.  
#oceanx #marinebiology #reef #underwater #discovery

node.text:
Update from the Arctic via @eerrp: We are now heading north—further north than I have ever been before. In fact, further from the equator then I've ever been. Even geosynchronous satellites that we get our internet from will be hidden by the horizon so this may be my last post for several weeks as we lose almost all connection with the rest of the world.

It's easy to take for granted how ubiquitous our connections to one another are. Please keep the rest of the world in okay shape while I'm gone, and catch you on the flip side ~~

#northpole #arcticexploration #nointernet #nophone #nothingbutnature #oceanxplorers

@oceanx @natgeotv @bbcstudios
